description.text:
I created this Pillow Block bearing holder, for a KP08 bearing on my FLSUN Cube. The stock bearings were kinda crappy, and had to be very precisely set (they did sit in the corner, so it shouldn't be an issue).

This is meant to screw into the 2020 rail on the inside of the cube. -- this has been pointed out that they should be on the outside of the cube, but for me, I am using my own designed corner brackets: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2655498 which allows me to put it on the inside

I use the square 4mm nuts that came with the cube, and 4x10 screws to secure the block to the mount. I use M5x10 screws to secure it to the rail, but feel free to use M4 (the hole can be used for either).

UPDATE

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Video clip of the mount in action:
http://gfycat.com/completefaircarpenterant

I'm not sure how well it will hold up yet, so I suggest using a tether from your chinstrap to the camera.

The idea behind this bracket was that I wanted to have a streamlined mount that did not look bolted on to the side of the helmet, or onto the top. I also wanted a chin-mounted GoPro mount, but sadly the Shoei RF-SR helmet has a chin area completely occupied by the intake vent. A clip on mount may work, but I have not started development on one.

The RF-1200 has a much better space for the mount. In addition, I wanted the GoPro to sit with the lens as close to the center line of the helmet as possible. For a standard GoPro this works well, but for the Session, the lens will be slightly off to the side.

As a final design goal, The chin vent needed to remain operable, so the slight offset helps with this too.

It is designed to fit on the lower right side of the helmet as pictured (affixed with double sided tape)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm

20%

Notes:

Printed with 2mm walls and 2mm top and bottom. Supports are important for this model as we want the GoPro mount section to align perfectly with the layer lines for maximum strength.

I updated the BLTouch mount that I originally created for the Tevo Tornado.

A couple of beneftis:

  • The wire routing hole is made to fit the dupont connectors without having to remove the wires
  • There's a hole that will let you access the screw for the X carriage wheel without having to take off the mount.
  • The mount fits a lot better now
  • The distance from the nozzle to the tip of the BLTouch is the same, so no need to change the firmware.
  • Also updated to add a hole so you can adjust the calibration screw on top of the BLTouch itself. - I'll leave both versions, but you'll probably want to print this one.

Installation instructions video below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mBwHGuX5de8

Thanks to thisiskeithb for the suggestions.

comments.text: According to BLT mounting instructions (https://store.timeshell.ca/image/cache/catalog/product-50/$_12%20(3)-500x500.JPG), the vertical distance between the base of the BLT body and the tip of the nozzle should be 8.3 +/-0.2. After installing this mount I find that the distance I get is 2.9mm so I am 5.4mm too low. Besides the ideal distance, being too high is better than being too low since the aforementioned situation can be fixed by adding spacers.
comments.author: Tamadite

comments.text: if you look at the official ANTCLABS instructions, their diagram shows the tip of the probe being 2mm above the tip of the nozzle. https://plus.google.com/113792662927481823969/posts/i7N4MzQBGmi
comments.author: Tamadite

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: Sevakp

comments.text: Did you install the springs between the BLTouch and the mount? Try raising your Z axis up about 100mm then homing all. When it starts lowering the z axis in the middle of the bed, push the pin of the BLTouch up by hand before it gets close to the bed.  If it stops moving, moves back up and starts moving down again then your bltouch is probably too high up so your nozzle hits the bed first. If it doesn't stop moving down, then turn off your printer so it doesn't crash into the bed again, and double check all of your wiring.
comments.author: Sevakp

title: Anet A6 Hot End Mod 25mm x 32mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This part was made for printing with ABS on an Anet A6 easier. This setup is not made for 120mm/sec and is useless anyway if the target is to print ABS. Something people like Thingiverse user MKSA have no experience with :-) See comment. :-)

Do you have a hot end with cool fin dimensions : diameter 22,25mm x 26mm? Please see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2252256

Do you have a hot end with cool fin dimensions : diameter 25mm x 32mm? Than you can use it with this model :-)

This is a x wagon that holds a cheap Chinese J-head like hot end. See picture.
The air for cooling the hot end fins is guided in such a way that it can never hit the printed parts. This is for making ABS printing more easy. See print screen.

A big advantage of this part is that changing filament is very easy. You can see where your filament wire go's. No more struggling with that original extruder :-)

On the bottom I placed some Kapton tape to protect the plastic and it helps to create an air tight seal.

You should be able to put this together with the screws and nut you got with your Anet A6 printer.

There are two types:
with PLA cooling fan support (main PLA Fan with support material.STL)
without PLA cooling fan support (main with support material.STL)
See print screen

In the main housing print support material is already in. It's a little cylinder on the place where the Hot End will be. See print screen.

---------------------------------All below is optional-------------------------------------------

BEWARE: It could be possible that you do not have enough clearance in the top of the Z axis. If you have that problem you can install “Anet A6 Left upper bracket for higher Z axis” :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2529991

In the pictures you can see that I also have installed a cooler on my stepper motor. For that part please see :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2347821
I had to break the bottom out to make the screw holes of the motor align with the mounting holes :-).

The cables to the controller are hold by the “Anet A6 Cable holder X wagon“:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2299852

printed in silver and gray ABS. 0.2mm resolution, 0.4mm nozzle at 222°C, bed 96°C (100°C would be better I guess. Still suffered a little bit of warping :-) ) on Kapton tape, with an Anet A6 (Anet A6 J-Hotend mod)

title: Jaguar Mk2 1959-69 Heater Control or Choke Knob C15719

description.text:
This is a replacement knob for the control lever for heater blend door and HVAC door on 1959-1969 Jaguar Mk2 and Daimler V8 250 models that use the original heater controls.

Reproduction knobs were AU$40 from the only supplier I could find that carried them.

Despite having one part number (Jaguar C15719), it looks like factory knob were side dependent, and had a specific left (blend door), and right (HVAC) knob, I've made this knob interchangeable left or right. The factory used what looks like a #4-40 flat bladed pan head screw to secure the knob with a thread directly on the control arm. I made this knob just snug enough on the lever arm that it retains itself. No evidence yet of how long that would last in everyday use though.

I printed with no raft or supports in black PLA.

description.text:
This is an adaptation of Hiruna's nicely-designed clips for fitting 300x300mm IKEA LOTS mirrors to the aluminium bed of the Creality CR-10 (mines a CR-10S which may account for some of the adjustments mentioned below).

BEFORE printing, please see Hiruna's version for a description of the printing orientation. I'll upload some more pictures when I have time.

I found the originals too loose, so I shrunk the height by 0.5 mm.

Note that I have my mirror slightly offset towards the front-left, not centred, and the clips have been adjusted accordingly. Because the clips are different, I have labelled them FL, FR, BR, BL for front-left, etc)

Also, I found the original clip for the cable restraining corner extremely difficult (not impossible) to fit, so I have remixed that one to have a long 'arm' across the back, that is much easier to fit. I have actually provided two version of that clip; the longer one is even easier to fit! You may need to lift off the restraining unit's cap in order to fit the clip to this corner; it just pops right off if you push to the plastic spring-clips in (light-pressure required; no need to force anything), then it clips back on.

Thanks to Hiruna for the original design - very neat, and I apologise for butchering it in TinkerCad!

Update (9th Jan 2018): The 'rearranged' STL that I uploaded, mistakenly only contained one of the clips, so I have deleted it. I have now uploaded the five clips in separate files (labelled FL for Front Left, FR for Front Right, etc) and placed them in printing orientation.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed these with eSun PLA+ and they're working fine, BUT I don't have the bed heat higher than 60°C. If you go higher than that, you'll need to print using ABS or PETG depending on your bed temperature requirements.
Modified from hiruna's original design. I imported the STL into Tinkercad, and have provided a link so you can copy and modify the design further if required.

A star-shaped fidget toy with 3d-print-in-place hinges. Inspired by the crane lamp fidget toy.

Update 2017-11-27: Now with stronger hinge pins & looser joints for easier first motion.

comments.text: cool! how did you do that animation in openscad?
comments.author: piDude

comments.text: In the .scad file, you'll see "n = 6" for printing and a commented-out "n = <big, complicated expression based on t>" for animation.  The big, complicated expression is what controls the movement -- hold it steady for awhile, then scale it gradually, both for n and for initial_r, alternating.

print_settings.Notes:: Two collars are required to hold the polarising film

description.text:
A Polarimeter is used to measure the angle of rotation caused by optically active substances, such as a sugar solution.

A yellow LED (585nm) in the base shines through a polarising film, through the sample in the tube, then through another polarising film in the cap.

First the user rotates the cap until the light they see through the cap is the darkest. Then the scale is rotated to match the 0 with the pointer on the cap. Next the sample is placed in a 16mm diameter test tube and put in the device. If the substance is optically active, the darkest point will have changed, which can be measured by rotating the cap and reading off the scale ring - this may be either to the left or right of zero.

The concentration of the sample in g/ml must be known, and the temperature.

Specific rotation is calculated by multiplying the height of the liquid in the test tube (in dm) by the concentration, then divide the observed angle of rotation by the result of that.

The specific rotation is written as the calculated angle followed by the temperature and wavelength, 585nm in this case.

Common examples are sucrose (table sugar) at +66 and Fructose at -92 degrees.

A famous experiment is to make a sucrose solution, measure/calculate the specific rotation, then add a drop of Hydrochloric or Sulphuric acid, then observe the change in rotation over time caused by the reaction.

Printer:

Tronxy X-1

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25% and 100%

Notes:

The Base should be printed upside-down with 10% supports, only-touching-buildplate.

Everything can be printed at 25% infill, but the cover is better at 100% to make the lugs stronger.

If you do not have a heated bed, use a brim when printing the tube.

Only 1 tube is required, depending on the length of your 16mm diameter test tubes.

Two collars are required to hold the polarising film

Two pieces of polarising film cut to 1cm x 1cm will fit into the square holes in the base and the cap. The Collar rings will push-fit tightly over them to fix them in place.

If your printer does not produce exactly round parts, some sanding may be required to allow the cap to rotate freely. The scale ring should be slightly stiff to prevent it moving by accident.

It is easier to do the battery/switch/LED wiring before assembling the rest of the device.

A spare hole in the base allows for another LED to be fitted to more easily show if the device is switched on or not.

Before fitting the scale ring, download and print a protractor and glue it to the ring.
A good protractor is http://clipart-library.com/clipart/yikredraT.htm#

No screws are required.

If battery cost/life is important, the on/off switch should be a push-button type and a 'joule thief' circuit added so that only 1 battery is required, which will still work even when the battery is almost totally empty.

The design was drawn in FreeCad 0.16

The battery holder is a slightly modified version of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2339441

It just needed a slot cutting out.

author: untkms

description.text:
This is not a mod for the faint of heart, it requires an almost complete disassembly of the printer base frame.
And probably a lot of swearing and frustration, but I am quite pleased of how it turned out.
I am marking it as a work in progress, since I plan to modify a few things to better fit readily available hardware and to come out with a bill of materials and a proper assembly sequence, eventually.
But if someone is daring enough to give it a try, here's the sources, have a go at it! :)

Here it is printing its own endstop brackets: https://youtu.be/2o1mKZOJG_4

I am intentionally only publishing the SCAD files, because you really need to know what you are doing before you tackle this. I have set up Marlin to be set in CoreYX mode (notice the exact spelling) and unless you use a recent release from the GIT repository it just won't home properly. Whenever you test movement leave the grub screws off the pinions until you are sure the motors are spinning in the right direction and the correct endstops are read. the pinions and idlers are from Anycubic, 16 teeth size which help improve both torque and resolution, and they fit over m3x30 bolts. I have some very tiny washers from my "PC bolts box" that allow them to spin freely, but probably it would be possible to make something equivalent by thinly slicing 3mm inner diameter PTFE tubing.
I am using Marlin 1.1.6 from the GIT repository, here are the main changes in configuration.h related to this mod:
#define COREYX //(uncomment this, note, YX, not XY)
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT { 100, 100, 2560, 640 }
//(using the standard M8 allthread rod, and E steps should be tweaked)
//(Note, I am using TMC2100 drivers, so the axes are ALL inverted
// compared to the stock drivers)
#define INVERT_X_DIR true
#define INVERT_Y_DIR true
#define INVERT_Z_DIR true

comments.text:
Certainly one of the worst kinematic for a 3D printer ! I like the grinding noise too.Must be unbearable when used at a decent speed.
Indeed, swearing and frustration guaranteed, from the building phase to the "printing" phase then back to the real CoreXY. phase.
OK, this "design" allows heavy bulky extruder, 1kg and more !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I have switched to TMC2100 drivers since I made the video, and they make a world of difference for noise. I have also modified the controller to run motors, fans and heaters at 24V, which might theoretically help a little with torque at higher speeds, but really mainly helps warming up the bed in a reasonable time.

My girlfriend got into crocheting and told me how difficult it was to crochet and hold her yarn at the same time. So I came up with this. This yarn holder comes in 2 pieces and does not need support. The only thing that is needed is a regular sized skateboard bearing (8mm inside/22mm outside). You might need to use a rubber mallet to squeeze the bearing into the top piece. To make sure the whole thing didn't move when you pulled on the yarn, 3/4 washers were placed around the center pillar to add weight. You can get these at Home Depot. Then just add a little Krazy glue around the inside of the bearing and stick it onto the bottom piece. Make sure to hold down when glueing and make sure its centered so that it doesn't spin at an angle.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

No

No

15

Yarn comes in many different sizes so I had to make a way so this holder would be compatible with all sizes. First I made the base and made a pillar to hold a skateboard bearing so that the top would spin. Then for the top part I just made an indention for the bearing to fit snug into place.

I designed it to measure the diameter of some round holes.

This lid replaces the top on the replicator and makes it possible to use the Minimalistic filament feeder on a replicator, including dual extrusion. Use together with the minimalistic feeder by whosawhatsis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15718 And cable strain relief:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21570

On a dual extrusion replicator:
  • Print this part, (I used 40% infill, no shell and it works great)
  • Print the minimalistic feeder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15718
  • Print the reverse feeder (available on the same page)
  • Mount it to your replicator
  • enjoy access to clean your gear and better compatibility with filament that aren't exactly 1.8mm

comments.text: Printing this out got me thinking: Assuming the top block is just meant to side-load the screws connecting the steppers to the fans, then it seems that the top block needs to rest on the heat sinks to keep it from tilting forward when the chromed screw is tightened. Furthermore, this block has the same problem I've seen on all the other designs thus far, where the electrical connectors to the stepper motors are incredibly difficult to access by hand.

author: KidSwidden

description.text:
This is a remix of the already great design made by user JaidynEdwards. It's scaled to 84mm x 42mm x 28mm to fit on my printer. I made the walls a uniform thickness and rounded a few corners, but other than that, it's still his (and Klemens Torggler's) design!
See the instruction tab for more info.

The assembly needs six (6) M3 x 8mm screws.  Clearance holes are sized at 3.6mm and tapped holes are sized at 3.2mm.  No reaming or drilling should be necessary.  
The lids are nearly identical, but the post heights vary.  Line up the rounded edges with the box to quickly fit them up.

Printed over the course of a week on my Tevo Tarantula at 0.4mm/0.2mm.
I spent ~8 hours on it.

  • Included the different weapon options I found on thingiverse
  • added bolts/nuts/rivets to everything
  • added a groin plate
  • completely redid the shin pads
  • added exhaust stacks
  • the main body piece had almost no detail so I added plenty of vents, plates etc.
  • modified the hood
  • modified the hip joints
  • shrunk the shoulder sockets slightly so they'd fit under the main body plate
  • probably some more stuff that i've forgotten about

Please refer to the original 'wardog titan' thing for assembly/part instructions. Note that some assemblies have been combined.

title: AA Battery Holder with belt attachment V2

description.text:
Holder for 4 x AA sized batteries, this version suits a 10mm camera strap. The body and lid are printed seperately and connected together using a 4x20mm round head with washer self tapping screw. You will also need 4 x 10x19mm compression springs

The design can be easily modified to suit alternate size straps/belts.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cSg4b4TG4BJ

Printer:

ANET A6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02

Infill:

25

After printing, I assembled the parts using a dab of araldite on each spring to hold them in place. The lid is secured in place with the self tapping screw done up enough to allow the lid to freely rotate. Once assembled the batteries are inserted with the posative terminal up bt pressing down against the spring and rotating the lid to hold it in place. The depressions on the undersode of the lid line up with the batteries and hold the access hole in an offset position to lock the batteries inside until needed.

author: Blips

description.text: Danke an Ostaryia!

This is an elastic band powered catapult. It can fire small projectiles. It is made in sketchup, and I have no idea how big or small it is, so if you want to make it you may have to scale it yourself. The angle at which the catapult stops, and therefore the angle of launch is adjusted by where you put the small pole.

Once printed, put the poles in the holes that they fit into. If some holes are too small, simply make them the right size with a file. The catapult head probably needs to be glued on to the catapult arm, and you should probably bash something into the ends of the thickest pole that has the arm in it. All you need after that is an elastic band, which you loop round the 'C' shaped holes, and around the arm, and you're ready to go!

comments.text:
When we printed it without scaling it, it came out about 9mm, but they admit at the library that they are using older Makerbot software for their machines (for some reason they won't update) so maybe there's some issue there. When I scaled it up, I added 2mm, I just measured it and it's 11mm in height, which was just enough.
Also we figured the duct tape maybe causing interference so maybe that wasn't a good idea after all :p
comments.author: rdominelli

comments.text:
Hi! We tried printing it again today, and it printed much better :) I guess there was an error when we imported the model, because it imported it up right and it scaled it down to "fit" the printer. We're new to 3D printing so it was an amateur mistake to not check the dimensions in Makerbot before we printed.
It was an almost perfect fit this time; width is perfect but a tad bit too short length wise to get the phone in. We also wouldn't mind a little bit more height so there is a lip to protect the front face of the phone. We'll try printing again tomorrow with an extra 2mm length and height.
Would also be nice to have an option with no hole in the back, I don't have enough experience in 3D design to fill that in.

description.text:
Remix des brides des chariots Z(x) disponibles ici :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2627287
et là
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2627391

Ces brides sont plus épaisses (de 1,5mm) que les originales, afin de reprendre totalement les efforts de tension de courroie X, sans déformer les tiges de guidages Z.

Voir les deux dernières images explicatives montrant le jeu de 3 mm sur les DiscoVery,
qui a été reproduit sur les DiscoEasy (...) , et qui a pour conséquence de déformer les structures Z et Y.

Si vous avez déjà corrigé ce gap de 3mm, avec des tiges de 273 mm ou avec 4x cales de 1,5 mm (ou juste 2x de 3 mm), ou que vous utilisez la pièce suivante, ce remix ne vous concerne pas. J'avais déjà mentionné et corrigé cette erreur dans cette pièce: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2478516

Il est également probable que l'ensemble de votre structure se soit déformée au fûr et à mesure de son usage avec les pièces d'origines Dagoma, dans ce cas faite des essais/erreurs en mixant ces nouvelles brides d'un côté et les anciennes de l'autres (...)

description.text: patte de fixation

print_settings.Notes:: The rounded part should fit directly over the entry hole for the bowden tube, leaving a piece sticking out over the gap between the extruder gear and the opposing bearing.  (That creates a channel for the filament to go through.)  Superglue the part to that point, with the overhanging piece as close to the gear and bearing as possible. It won't matter too much if they're touching slightly: it'll just wear that part away and produce a snug channel.

description.text:
We have a Velleman 3D pen which started jamming a little while back.

https://www.velleman.eu/products/view/?id=420418

On investigation, it turns out that the entry path for filament through the extruder is a little too free: it's very easy for the filament to go out of the extruder and either push down the side of the internal bowden tube, or actually push against the bowden tube entry so hard that it damages the tube entry point.

So I've designed this little repair piece which can be superglued onto the bowden entry point. It encloses the filament path for the extruder.

Hypercube

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

This is a very small part so it'll probably need a bit of brim to make it stick properly to your print surface.

The rounded part should fit directly over the entry hole for the bowden tube, leaving a piece sticking out over the gap between the extruder gear and the opposing bearing. (That creates a channel for the filament to go through.) Superglue the part to that point, with the overhanging piece as close to the gear and bearing as possible. It won't matter too much if they're touching slightly: it'll just wear that part away and produce a snug channel.

title: Tinkering the Ivan Miranda Big Printer to a smaller version (Completed)

description.text:
The original design of this printer lays in the hands of Ivan Miranda.
More info about this printer design can be found here https://ivanmiranda.com/?p=1645
No doubt to say, we love this design due it's simplicity in configuration and build. Thumbs up for Ivan.

As this is a very BIG printer, 300 x 600 x 300 mm, we at 3D Prototype Printing decided to adjust a bit of the dimensions, 300 x 300 x 500 mm, as that suits us more.

Using the B.O.M. posted by Ivan, we simply redone the numbers of the posted lengths towards the rods, the 20 x 20 x 1.5 mm square aluminum extrusions and the M8 Lead screw to get what we needed.

Either we made a mistake in the mats, or the print area is not 300 x 600 mm posted.
We came out (after the build) on 195 x 295 mm with a height of 450 mm,
20 mm should be added in the y direction, 105 mm + the size of the carriage should be added to the x direction (about 185 mm). and 50 mm into the z direction

Note: If you going to make use of the new type "Bed holder" then the Z direction only needs to be corrected with 20 mm.

As we wanted to have this printer in prototype state, we opted for cheaper materials.
For example, the smooth rods have been replaced with chromed stainless steel pipes of 12mm, the x bridging has been replaced with an aluminum 8mm rod. The bed is made out of wood, yes, no metal as we don't use a heated bed. Still, we most likely stay with the wooden bed, or a printed version for it with use of extra insulation materials.

After cutting all materials to length and printing all the posted parts from his Fusion 360 link https://myhub.autodesk360.com/ue29ae852/g/shares/SH7f1edQT22b515c761eda136a61687c5365 we started to build the printer.
On his website he wrote about using this Fusion 360 to update all his parts. We came to the conclusion that this was not fully true. During his build he made adjustments to the printer that did not show up in this build. But that didn't matter as some of his adjustments are on his webpage (link above).

We noticed, after printing the Y-Carriage, the holes for the LM12UU were like 1 mm to large, strange as he used his screwdriver to hammer them in, ours just made use of the gravity, Tinkering was needed to get this printer going like we wanted it to go, after all we had almost all the parts available.
One thing that we were missing was a holder for the filament stepper, already posted here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2630201.

Ivan his design of the bed is of a massive weight, 2 times 6 mm aluminum plate, 3 cork layers, a 300 x 600 mm mirror, 2 heat beds of 300 x 300 mm and 2 solid state relays mounted to the bottom of the print bed. (HEAVY)

We wanted to go light so that is why we used the wood. Problem we got with that is, it is shaking all over the place do not enough weight, though we stick on the wood for now and see if we can come to a solution. (already redesigned a few parts for it)

First of all this:

Parts that you can print straight of the original build.
This list shows the parts we used without any adjustments, off course you can print all the originals from Ivan his design as we did also to start with.

Overall list of original parts, used by 3DPP:
T2020 20x needed
E2020 20x needed
Bracket front (2 parts for power supply)
Bracket back (2 parts for power supply)
LCD Screen (4 parts including the reset knob)
Arduino Ramps Controler (2 parts)
End Stop Support (Limit Switch) (2 parts) (Probably will be updated for Dual Z- Limit Switch Support)

X-Axis parts (Although those parts are called Y-, from my point of view, the position / placing of the LCD makes those X- related)
Y-Guide Bracket Motor (2 parts, part for X-axis motion of the Y-axis, holds the dual axis NEMA 17, locking the X-axis)
Y-Guide Bracket (1 part, holds the 608 bearing to guide the rod coming from Y-Guide Bracket Motor, locking the X-axis (use Y-Guide Bracket Upper))
Y-Guide Bracket Upper (1 part (3x needed) to clamp the 12 mm X-Axis rods in place)
Bracket Tensioner (1 part, Part to lock the 12 mm X-Axis (use Y-Guide Bracket Upper) and the GT2 Belt Tensioner)
Bracket Tensioner mirror (1 part, Part to lock the 12 mm X-Axis (use Y-Guide Bracket Upper) and the GT2 Belt Tensioner)
Belt Tensioner (3x needed)

Y-Axis parts
Bridge Motor Side (1 part, the top part of the bridge that holds the NEMA in place)
All other parts of the Y-Axis are modified.
Still you can print all the originals, all up to you.

Z-Axis parts
The Z-Axis consist out of 4 parts, the motor holder (2x needed), the clamp for the motor holder (2x needed), the bed holder (2x needed) and the clamp for the guide rail on the bottom (4x needed).
Point of attention:
If you donwload the files from Fusion 360, the motor holder and the clamp for the motor holder missing the hole to lock the guide rail in place.
Only part we used:
Clamp Guide Rail Bottom (4x needed)
All other parts of the Z-Axis are modified.
Still you can print all the originals, all up to you.

We will frequently update this page (until done) with all the updates.

So for all that are making this printer or planning to make this printer, those updates might be useful to you.

Note: All settings posted are the settings we used, feel free if you want to change them to make it more stirdy.

The updates:

  1. Reducing the M8 Lead screw wobbling: added a holder to the bottom with an extra 608 bearing (3 Parts to print, 0.2 layer, 40% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    z-axis 12mm centering guide bottom bearing (print laying on the side)
    z-axis 12mm centering guide bottom
    z-axis 608zz locker (any 608 will do)

  2. Avoiding running out of the M8 nut from the Bed Plate Holder on long Z-Axis travel (minor update if you use the original Bed Plate Holder)
    Nut Lock Plate (2x needed) 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  3. Guide rod holder for Z-Axis to replace the Limit Switch Holder (preparing for dual Z limit Switch)
    axis holder 12mm 35 mm inside frame (1x needed) 0.2 layer, 20% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Axis holder 12mm 35mm outside frame with cable tray (1x needed) 0.2 layer, 20% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Limit Switch holder to fit on 35 mm axis holder (2x needed if you go for dual Z Limit Switch) 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  4. Replacement for the Bed Holders, those will replace the ones that are shown in post 2. Switching from 1 guided rod to 2 guided rods on the Z-Axis.
    Bed holder (2x needed 0.2 layer, 30% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    M8 Nut holder (2x needed 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  5. Spool Holder, we need a spool holder. Despite there are a zillion on TV, i could not find one made for the 20 x 20 mm square tube, also needs to be able to hold a 300 mm spool.
    20 x 20 clamp for spool holder (2x needed) 0.2 layer, 20% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Spool Holder (1x needed) 0.2 layer, 30% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  6. X-Motor carriage: Changed to have a better alignment when locking the rods in place and a clamp mechanism to have the belt more secure and easier mounting. The LM12UU has a very snug fit.
    X-carriage Bridge Motor side (1x needed) 0.2 layer, 30% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Cable holder V2 right hand side (1x needed per X-carriage 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Cable holder V2 left hand side (1x needed per X-carriage 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  7. X-carriage Bridge Pulley side. Changed to have a better alignment when locking the rods in place and a clamp mechanism to have the belt more secure and easier mounting. The LM12UU has a very snug fit.
    X-carriage Bridge Pulley side (1x needed) 0.2 layer, 30% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Cable holder V2 right hand side (1x needed per X-carriage 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    Cable holder V2 left hand side (1x needed per X-carriage 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  8. Y-Carriage. Changed to carry 30 mm fan mounting spots (extruder + part cooling). The LM12UU has a very snug fit. Designed to fit a Heatsink of 31 / 32 mm in max height (Total height of all the cooling ribs). The part cooling fan positioned at the bottom need to be slide in from the side, only 2 screws needed to keep it in place.
    Y-Carriage (1x needed) 0.2 layer, 40% infill, no rafts, supports needed, see photo's)
    Y-Carriage Belt clamp (2x needed 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)
    E3D Clamp (1x needed 0.2 layer, 100% infill, no rafts, no supports)

  9. NOTE
    For the Y-Carriage, print it at 30 mm/s.
    The last photo shows the carriage after a 5 and a half hour print on 205 C. Yes, it is just PLA.

Raw, non calibrated printer Benchy test as result after all the updates. Printed at 0.2 layer @ 60 mm/s.

Done
In case we come up with more updates, we will off-course post them.
3DPP wish all the people that are building or planning on building this printer "Happy Printing"

description.header: How to activate dual Z Endstop in Marlin 1.8.1
description.text:
In Configuration_adv.h

Go to the section to uncomment // #define Z_DUAL_ENDSTOPS

//===========================================================================
//============================ Mechanical Settings ==========================
//===========================================================================

// A single Z stepper driver is usually used to drive 2 stepper motors.
// Uncomment this option to use a separate stepper driver for each Z axis motor.
// The next unused E driver will be assigned to the second Z stepper.
'#define Z_DUAL_STEPPER_DRIVERS

'#if ENABLED(Z_DUAL_STEPPER_DRIVERS)

// Z_DUAL_ENDSTOPS is a feature to enable the use of 2 endstops for both Z steppers - Let's call them Z stepper and Z2 stepper.
// That way the machine is capable to align the bed during home, since both Z steppers are homed.
// There is also an implementation of M666 (software endstops adjustment) to this feature.
// After Z homing, this adjustment is applied to just one of the steppers in order to align the bed.
// One just need to home the Z axis and measure the distance difference between both Z axis and apply the math: Z adjust = Z - Z2.
// If the Z stepper axis is closer to the bed, the measure Z > Z2 (yes, it is.. think about it) and the Z adjust would be positive.
// Play a little bit with small adjustments (0.5mm) and check the behaviour.
// The M119 (endstops report) will start reporting the Z2 Endstop as well.

' #define Z_DUAL_ENDSTOPS

' #if ENABLED(Z_DUAL_ENDSTOPS)
' #define Z2_USE_ENDSTOP ZMAX
' #define Z_DUAL_ENDSTOPS_ADJUSTMENT 0 // Use M666 to determine/test this value
'#endif

'#endif // Z_DUAL_STEPPER_DRIVERS

Then do not forget to go into Configuration.h

go to the section to uncomment // #define USE_ZMAX_PLUG

//===========================================================================
//============================== Endstop Settings ===========================
//===========================================================================

// @section homing

// Specify here all the endstop connectors that are connected to any endstop or probe.
// Almost all printers will be using one per axis. Probes will use one or more of the
// extra connectors. Leave undefined any used for non-endstop and non-probe purposes.
'#define USE_XMIN_PLUG
'#define USE_YMIN_PLUG
'#define USE_ZMIN_PLUG
//#define USE_XMAX_PLUG
//#define USE_YMAX_PLUG
'#define USE_ZMAX_PLUG

That is if you going to use the ZMAX end stop.
Standard XMAX is set in Configuration_adv.h

Do NOT alter the ' i placed in front of the lines, those avoid the change of the line in a Hugh font.
Hope this might help you out.

description.text:
Just Added: MK2 with added arms to hold the watch securely.

Just got the Fossil Q Explorist Smartwatch, but coming from a Motorola 360, I am used to a charging dock.
Therefore, here is a charging dock to hold your watch when you charge it - usually for overnight charges, allowing you to use it as a sort of bedside clock like you can with the Moto 360. I have designed it so it could work with any type of strap, including a metal link strap, although you must then slot the cable back through the centre hole like in the pictures.

If your watch uses the same sort of magnetic disc charger, it may well work for your watch too.

You must stick the charging disc into the circular slot - I used some double sided tape, anything stronger and I would worry that you may not get it back out again when needed.

I advise sticking rubber/silicone/foam feet on the bottom, or failing that, small blobs of blue-tac on each corner.

author: UKDTweak

description.text:
For years I've been frustrated that I couldn't find something like a tackle or customizable parts box where you could make arbitrary sized and shaped containers.  I decided to design one using pegboard and printed parts, this is the result.  
Here I'm using it with 1' x 2' pegboard as a tray to organize miniatures for gaming.  
See Instructions for details on how to use.

These have a place for a captive nut in the top. Use #10 nuts (imperial) with #10 1 3/4" machine screws. This is designed to hold strips of 1/4" thick, 1 1/2" wide wood strips (common at home depot and such). Cut the wood strips to:
  • 1 3/8" for crossing 1 hole
  • 2 3/8" for crossing 2 holes
  • 3 3/8" for crossing 3 holes
    • (you see the pattern here)
OpenBuilds based design for automated storage of microplates in a stack.

Instructions are a work in progress!

You will need:
All the STL files, printed with decent infill. 1 copy of each apart from plateholder.scad where you will need a set of 4 to support 6 plates. 8, for 12, 12 for 18, etc.

Lots of 20x20 V slot extrusion (you can decide the dimensions, but the width between the uprights should probably be 100mm)
A load of M5 V-slot T-nuts, M5 bolts, and right angle brackets
A few M3 bolts for mounting motors
2 mini-V gantries, one for Z axis and one for X axis
2 NEMA17 motors
GT2 timing belt and one pulley
X axis: 2 606ZZ bearings as further timing belt pulleys, and some M6 bolts to hang them on, and washers to keep the belt in place.
Z axis: 8mm ACME leadscrew and nut, 608ZZ bearing to hold it at the top.

The plate that actually picks up the plate needs to be thin, so probably has to be made of (stainless) steel. It should be narrow enough to fit between the plate holder pieces. I bought an offcut with 1.6mm thickness and cut it with an angle-grinder, then drilled holes in it to connect to the X gantry and to the belt clamp piece.

Paint the plateholder.stl files (which mount to the open beam) in PlastiDip paint so they grip better. Same for the stainless steel plate.

Control it with a 3D printer board, e.g. RAMPs and Arduino.

More to come.

For those who play Massmorra, I found it helpful to have extra tokens to track user abilities that generate symbols instead of dice.

Both single and dual color prints.

I designed a modular animatronic eye with commonly available parts. The eye module has up/down and left/ right movement as well as individually controllable top and bottom eyelids. It started with only an eye module but quickly grew to be an entire head. I only upload the eye for now because this is the most useful part. The rest is pretty custom. Made in the future I upload the rest.

The eye module size is only:

  • 100mm long
  • 45mm width
  • 30mm height

All the parts where printed in ABS and treated with an acetone vapour bath to make everything very smooth. After the vapour bath all holes were drilled to the correct size because the ABS would deform a little during the process. Please note that some parts require extra sanding to make all parts fit. For example the eyelids have extra material around the holes for the ball bearings to make it easier to print. Don’t sand away to much material because the ABS will crack when pressing in the ball bearing(I messed up quite a few this way)

This is a list of all the hardware I used to made one eye:

  • 4X MG90S mini servo
  • 1x 22mm Reborn eye
  • 6x MF63zz ball bearing
  • 34x M2 nut
  • 4x M3 lock nut
  • 28x M2x12 screw
  • 4x M2x5 screw
  • 2x M3x12 screw
  • 2x M3x12 screw sunk head
  • 1x M3x10 screw sunk head
  • 1x M3x10 hex spacer
  • 1x Tamiya 5mm Ball Connector Long (19805825)
  • 2x Tamiya 5mm Stabilizer Ball (15385)
  • 2x Ball and roller link 3.9x2x16mm (230060x10)
  • 2x 57x2mm rod with threat(old bicycle spoke)
  • 2x 22x2mm rod (old bicycle spoke)
  • 8x cable shoe with 2mm hole

I heated the three ball joints with a lighter and pressed them in the Eye coupler. When the plastic was still warm I pressed the plastic down to prevent the balls to pop out of the coupler. After some wiggling around the balls would move smoothly.

I used cable shoes which I modified a bit for the connecting rods but this is not an exact science. You can used other ways like Pushrod Linkage Stoppers or Ball connectors. I just didn’t have enough of these parts so I used the cable shoes.

When you want to make a pair of eye’s like I did. You just need to mirror all the parts and connect them together with two M2 spacers. All servo cables can exit through to back. I used 10mm spacers to make them as close together as possible but you can used any size you want. If you want a row of ten eyes or a dual row of eyes just keep coupling them together.

The sandwich plates are there because it wasn’t as solid as I hoped. There was a little bit of flex between two modules. So I made two plates out of 3mm acrylic. This made it very solid.

I made a short video to demonstrate the head.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=92OUb4uLUhk

All servo’s are controlled by a 32ch servo controller running a script on my laptop and sending commands to the controller over USB. These controllers are widely available on Ebay and other sites.

description.text:
Tired of strapping your hockey stick to your bikes with bungee cords?
Well these snap fit clips will do the trick.
The model is designed for a bike frame with a diameter of 29mm.
Obviously you'd need a set of at least 2 to make it work.

All you need is an M3 20mm screw and bolt for the hinge. Or a nail of any piece of metal that'll fit but probably not a toothpick.

There are 2 braces options. Skinny and Fat. I personally find the fat one a bit more stable but they really both work.

title: 20oz & 30oz Tumbler Handle for YETI, RTIC, Ozark Trail

description.text:
I remixed this from brandonmjor's 30oz handle to fit my collection of 20oz and 30oz mugs

There are two 20oz STLs included. One for Ozark Trail and RTIC brand tumblers and one with a .5mm wider opening that works for YETI. You can always scale the STL in your slicer if you want to adjust it higher or lower on your cup.

Update: I've added a 30oz model for the larger tumblers. Same design, just slightly beefed up and larger. The 30oz STL fits the RTIC and YETI brand 30oz tumblers.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed this in Priline PETG (http://a.co/emnqTWA) and it came out fantastic. PETG has the right amount of flex and strength for a part like this. I used .2mm and 50% infill and used Slic3r's defaults for PET and just changed infill to 50%.

I'm not sure if this would work well in PLA, it may need to be "beefed" up for PLA since I really designed it for PETG's strength and flex. If you haven't used PETG yet, I would strongly recommend you try it.

Parametric timing belt tooth profile-based SCAD scripts for generating belt cogs and dogs to be incorporated in your motion control designs.
Dogs are like clamps - they keep the belt in one place relative to the part they are placed on. I use them on my x carriage - no fasteners required!
The cog module makes a cog primative - add features as you like!
Presently limited to only T5 and T2.5 as those are the only belts I have to test with. Please add to the profile library!

Hopefully the code is clear enough. I'd appreciate feedback on how to do some of this better. Keeping things 2-manifold proved a challenge and I'd appreciate knowing if anyone has figured out how to build point arrays dynamically or concatenate point arrays in OpenSCAD.

title: Articulated Dragoness

description.text:
This is one of my ultimate goals in 3d printing to build my own Articulated Dragon.

i was want build dragon. but not enough to called be dragon. i still confused diffrence between each dragon types.

the name of model has chaged from the Articulated serpent to Articulated dragoness as two 'serpent' models had me confused between them as one is near similar to dragon and other one is define of serpent.

inspired by famous Braq the Dragon by BqLabs and other dragons as i take referrence for dragon anatomy. ball joint concept is inherited from my other ball jointed projects.

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10

Notes:

Just first at Neck 001 and 002 then if pited in well then you shall procssed as below

Head , Jaw, Eye - Neck set- Body 01 - Fore legs set which i expect use of mirror for opposite side - Body 02 - Body 03 - Back legs set as fore leged one - Tail set - Wings sets.

if you failed in middle of project due to design error then please let me know to fix that error at least trying.

Jen 29, 2018
Neck adpter for Sea serpent head. it allowed attach Sea sepent's head on this dragoness. additional re-scaling is doesn't require. just put Neck_Adapter part between Sea serpent's head and neck 001.

when build this, i was still in study this kind of ball joint and it tend to get loose as it lose tension.

the Wing and claw parts are vulnerable to rip off from it's soket. probably becauese it did not had enough space to strong holding soket like other ones which it is one of most i regret in design.

another part that i reget was the wing it self. i was consider just copycat Braq's wing structure a bit but i insist wing have to able fold correctly but in return wing end up being Bone dragon's wing...

i continued planning and Working on future generation articulated dragons.

description.text:
Warning work in progress!

10 and 12 mm dia low force and speed linear bearings for 19mm dia housing, 26mm long.
This is a compliant linear bearing for low force and speed application such as the X carriage on the Hypercube evolution.

The bearings for the X axis if using carbon fibre rods can be difficult to get working effectively. The carbon rods are not uniform in diameter or perfectly round, the x carriage bearing holder may not be perfectly straight along its axis, the tightening or fit of the bearing in the x carriage affects the bearing fit, the x carriage may not have parallel axis separation and the separation may not match XY carriage joiner and the XY joiners may have twist.

The compliant linear bearing is aimed to try and address this by allowing the inner part of the bearing to move slightly and alter angle by only having a small amount of material joining the inner and outer and by having the bearing proportion made of a thin shell so it can confirm to shape of tube which helps the bearing to move more freely without allowing much movement with the typical forces encountered with 3 d printing. It requires two bearings on one axis in order something to be located axially, and could be used with just one for the second axis.

This is early version and has not been tested much, only on my printer which has not seen much use.

The little flange on the top is to engage with tightening screw to stop it coming out of X carriage if screw loosens on X carriage from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437440 but did have to drill out that X carriage for 12mm tube clearance. I will alter with CAD next time and upload.
Just cut off flange if not required and it is in the way.

If required I will add other versions/sizes without flange etc.

Added in some parts which I used to get 12mm dia x axis rods/tube working with.
All additional parts are remixes of the original Hypercube Evolution parts form Scott's design.
XY Joiner which uses standard Y dimensions, but has 12mm X rod using standard X axis separation. XY Joiner endcaps to suit, plain ended variation and screw thread insert version to lock X rods/tube. There is also 12mmdia Y end stop flag.

Notes:

The main cylindrical sections are 1.2mm thick, but check in your slicer that you are fully filling with concentric lines. I had to reduce my line thickness slightly or I would only get an inner and outer shell and bit of infill here and there.

Probably needs to be printed slow, so probably print more than one at a time if not using a material with cooling fan.

This is for getting organised with your A3 sheets, instead of keeping them in a big pile on the floor. It's a similar design to a filing cabinet, where the sheets are kept in folders, which slide back and forth on the rack. It consists of
A) A Rack (Laser cut plywood, held together with nuts and machine screws)
B) Folders (cardboard and dowels) Work in progress - a bottom section for A3 folder storage will also be added.

=== To make the rack: ===  
1) Get some plywood. The stuff i've used was a weird size (3.8mm thick - or more likely 9/64 in imperial measures) and the slots have been designed for this, so if you've a different thickness you'll need to edit the slot size.  
2) Laser cut the sides and rails (4 each).  
3) Secure the sides in an X shape with six 3mm machine screws and nuts.  
4) Slot in the rails. Rack done!  
=== To make the folders ===  
1) Get some cardboard. Cut as many folders as you like. Dimensions: 760 x 450. Keep the "grain" of the cardboard parallel to the short edge - makes it easier to fold.  
2) Make the cardboard pieces into pockets by folding them in half.  
3) Now to turn them into sliding folders. Get some wooden dowels roughly 500mm long (i used 3mm diameter). You'll need 2 per folder.  
4) Fold over the top 30mm of each free end of the pocket. The dowels go in this fold. Staple them down so that the dowels stay in the fold. (you'll need to give the stapler a good bash depending on the thickness of the cardboard)  
Repeat for as many folders as you require.  
Done! Put your A3 sheets in the pockets and enjoy a more organised sliding filing system.

A tea infuser. That's what it is. Basically. Here's a video on how it works :https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JRuU1iWQQ7A

Make sure your printer is capable of bridging before you waste tons of filament.

Drink tea, have fun.

No

70%, Rectilinear

Notes:

This model was designed to be used with a 0.6 nozzle. You'd need to modifiy the CAD file to print it corretly with another nozzle ( i guess, but please prove me wrong ;) )

The trick to get the net surface is to ask you printer for 0 top and bottom layers, so that the infill pattern becomes the net ;)
I remarked that asking for 1 perimeter only helped the bridging, i've attached the slic3r config that worked best for me.

Again, make sure you use a foodsafe, heat resistant material. Mine is Extrudr GreenTEC.

title: MSI GTX 980 TI Corsair H55 Water Cooler

description.text:
PERFORM AT YOUR OWN RISK!

Personally tested, do not recommend. Coolant flow rate is very too low and has difficulties to bleed air bubbles. This solution is much better https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2700102

Corsair H55 Water Cooler adapter to work on a MSI GTX 980 TI 6G Gaming.

I had the tubes replaced, so that I could attach them into my main loop. Can make a video, if demand arrises, on how to replace the tubing. Use the factory screws and nuts, tighten till the PCB then un-tighten slightly not to damage the card. I put a small case fan over the capacitors to keep them cool, due to a lack of fans blowing air over them.

Temperatures decreased from high 80C on an overclock benchmarking, to 50C overclocked. Please keep in mind that I have a triple radiator setup with my water pump and fans running at full speed for the test.

(Apologies for the bad print, was a test of concept and forgot to take pictures of the final build. Attached a picture built into my PC).

author: NitzscheModellbau

description.text:
Why would you just tell the time, when you could tell the time from a watch on a 3D printed watch band! This is a 3D printable one-piece watch band that is strong, functional and light. It fits watches that have a 22mm lug width, and a lug to lug distance of 46.2mm (I designed it to fit a Seiko SNDA65 watch).
If enough people are interested, I can design a few more sizes, and size the lug to lug distance for various watches! I posted the design process for this watch band on my blog: http://colin-ho.com/3d-printed-watch-band/

Makerbot printing settings:
I printed it on a Makerbot replicator with the default slicing settings, with a raft, object infill of 100% and 2 shells. Post print assembly:

  • After printing is done, take a small file and carefully smooth out the male and female sides of the watch band clasp until they slide and mate snugly (tight enough to no fall out, loose enough to easily take off)

  • Take a thin metal rod (like a small allen key) and insert it through the spring-bar holes to make sure that the spring bars have no obstructions.

  • Attach the watch one spring bar at a time!

  • Enjoy the awesomeness of having a 3D printed watch band!

author: DiegoGab

description.text:
When I was adding a Z-Opto-Endstop to the RepRap that I had made for the Museum of Science in Boston, I didn't want to glue the Opto-Endflag to anything, so I made this holder. It was adapted from the endstop holder in the Prusa IT2 design. Video of that RepRap performing its first Z-homing with this part is here: http://youtu.be/zNhn5zM340Q The Opto-Endstop holder also pictured is:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21654
with a mirrored arm:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:266696

Print the object. Create a tin opto-flag from a tin can using tin snips. Wrap the end with blue masking tape so it isn't reflective. Line it up with the printed part and mark the hole locations. Drill holes in the metal flag with an M4 drill bit or something close. Use two M4 bolts to hold the flag onto the holder (I think.. maybe they were M3?). Use an M3 bolt to fasten the holder onto the X-axis.

author: UKDTweak

title: Filament Spool for Small Filament Amounts

description.text:
I bought a multi-pack of PLA filament for a 3D pen and needed a way to spool it out for my printer. I use a lot of Tianse PLA and have setup my printer with a spool holder for the size of the Tianse rolls, so I decided to make a small spool holder that is the same width as the rolls I typically use (so I don't have to adjust my spool holders).

I designed it so that one end pops off so it is easy to load and unload the filament samples. I also like the spools that have holes in them to thread the filament through when storing them to keep them from 'rolling' back on themselves, so I added some to this design.

This isn't my best print ever, but it was functional so I kept it.

title: Wanhao i3/plus/whatever fits. Spoolholder with bearing!

description.text:
Tested! all parts fit.
All you need is.
Bearing : Outer D, 28mm. Inner D, 11,94. Width, 8mm.

Can be printed in PLA, plenty strong! Designed in a way where all the forces is pull/compress.
The bracket that connects to the bearing is made as strong and simple as possible. It not only goes into the bearing, but it also have a "lip" that covers the outside as well for maximum support.

Why do you need this?
The default spoolholder isnt good enough and because of the friction between the spool/arm, you might see gaps or uneven layers on your prints. With this version, even a heavy spool is easy for the extruder motor to pull. Can easily be scaled up for the biggest of spools!

All files are uploaded here to make it as simple as possible for everyone to adjust and modify.

Use this to align the Ultimaker X and Y axes, to make them perpendicular.
This tool was cut from an alien bone. It wants to help you. Its true motive remains unclear. It's  probably friendly, but replicate it at your own risk.

• Print two bones, one of them mirrored (so you can mate them after use).

  • Loosen one pulley belt on both sides.

  • Push the big and the small claw into the matching rods, on both ends at the same time.
    • Make sure you also have http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8781 ready at hand.

title: Leapfrog Creatr Z sensor bracket with cable clip

description.text:
Replacement Z-axis sensor bracket for the Leapfrog Creatr.
Orients the capacitive senor vertically for better homing repeatability. Similar to versions by chickan and Korsar.
Includes a clip in the back for cable management.
When removing the original sensor bracket, make sure to place something in the extrusion slot to prevent the nut from falling into the bottom of the printer.

comments.text:
Thank You for this thing. it solves some problems with Z position and calibration.
One strange question, please. Did You ever see strange effect with LeapFrog - it's Zhome "swimming" or it's only mine LeapFrog defect? I modified my one to improve stability
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1499075
but one problem wasn't solved - sometimes HotBed stops with delta about 0.1-0.2 mm, of cause it's very bad. It seems to me that it depends on HotBed temperature. Before my modification I paid no attention because I thought it'll go away with ending of alu frame deformations. After modification of alu frame all deformations go away or become stable, but this one problem is alive.
Sorry. I have no FaceBook account and don't want hear anything about it.
comments.author: andyfox

comments.text: Hi. The glass bed warps slightly as it is heated. About the only thing you can do is try to reduce the air flow around the printer so that the temperature stays as consistent as possible.. Some people cover the openings to try to do this. However, there is some risk of causing the electronics to over heat.
comments.author: andyfox

comments.text: I understood reason why LeapFrog made this construction. It made to minimize depedence Z0 from temperature. After controlled covering of printer hotbed position changed 0.03-0.05 mm after heating (when temperature of the sensor changed fom 25C to approx. 45C). But table deformation is about 0.1-0.2 mm when hot bed warms till 80-90C. I despaired  to correct it in hardware, now I'm testing my correcting this problem software (it corrects G-code to real hotbed Z under hotend according previosly measured heights and some calculated values ).
comments.author: Festus440

comments.text:
Thank You for answer.
I wouldn't cover printer because it 'll quickly damage it's motors.
But it seems to me that hot air from bed goes on inductive Z-sensor and it begins to work.wrong way. When I find 2-3 hours (it's fantastic for me) I'll make another construction and try to remove Z-sensor from hot bed as far as possible (of cause saving it's vertical orientation). I think LeapFrog engeneer(s) saw and explored this problem and we see their solution in original design (where Z-sensor is rather far from hot area).
comments.author: Festus440

comments.text: Thanks Festus, your bracket removed a lot of problems I was having with my secondhand Leapfrog Creatr. And thanks to Nick for giving me the link to your thingme. Willy
comments.author: willycan

comments.text: Thanks. Glad to know if worked for you.
comments.author: willycan

comments.text:
Thanks!
You're right. The feed tubes can potentially get in the way.
That's one reason I moved the filament reel to the side of the printer:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:372769

title: Gloomhaven updated monster standee base and openscad sources

description.text:
Now that I have Gloomhaven, I have updated the Monster Standee Holder to be more functional!

  • Moved the current hit point indicator to the front (recommend sharpie to darken tip)
  • Moved the condition holder to in front of the Standee holder so you could see them! Duh!
  • Same great number spinners (also recommend sharpie to make the numbers stand out)
  • Same great standee holder

As before, I used the following as inspiration but I remade them all in openscad so I could tweak them easily.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2352889
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:875636
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:749229

No

No

0.1 or 0.2

40%

comments.text: What about making better room for the conditions? the overall size seem to stretch outside of the hexagon. Maybe put the monster in the middle and have his conditions on the other size. Thus constraining the overall token to the size of a hex tile?
comments.author: Todilo

comments.text: Hey, please check out my updated holder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2749386 - I included an overhead picture to show that the holders fit in the map hexes. Note that this revision is the same hex dimension as the new one so they would be the same. I have had 6+ all together before and never had an issue with standees interfering, although it is probably true that the bigger standees may slightly overhang the hex. Note if you want the conditions on the other side of the standee, you can check out my previous revision (see where remixed from) but note that then you can't see the conditions because the standee is in the way, which is why I updated it in this revision.
comments.author: Todilo

title: Lightsaber Creation Kit -> Stuff for a lit blade

description.text:
I wanted to have a blade for my sabers that light up.
Of course, I tried to keep it DIY and cheap.

The files are for a holder that slides in the handle and fits a 18650 lithium battery and has 4 slits for cables (.075mm²). As in the pictures I just glued everything in with hot glue.
Then there's a holder for the lens of the COB LED and a small cap for the top of the blade.

The blade is a colored plastic cover for a neon tube light. It's cheap and keeps the color, even when turned off. (I bought a 1490mm long tube and cut it in half for two sabers)

You will need the following:
1x flashlight from China (http://bit.ly/2hQbR2X)
1x blade, inner diameter 26,5mm (http://ebay.eu/2hUEJqJ)
1x 18650 lithium battery (harvested from an old laptop)
1x TP4056 lithium charger (http://bit.ly/2n3P21h)
1x piece of milky white foil the same size as your blade
1x small piece of reflective foil

I wrapped the milky foil about 3-4 times around a thin long wodden dowl, slid it in the blade and then turned the dowl the other way around, the foil sticks to the blade on it's own. Then I added a reflective foil on the top cap and glued it on the blade with super glue. Same goes for the lens holder.
I used the switch from the flashlight and glued it inside the saber, same as the charger. Wired everything up and it works like a charm!

The battery also gives the whole thin a nice "heavy" feel. The picture on the scale is without the blade.

I wanted to keep a "clean" look without any holes so to charge the battery you'll need to remove the bottom part, but thanks to schmots it's super easy to screw on and off!

title: Hex Vase 06
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I designed this as a bed level calibration print for my recently built Tevo Little Monster: As modeled, it's about 10.5" across, but you of course can scale it to any size you want.

Printer:

Tevo Little Monster

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Notes:

I printed this @ 200 microns, with '2 floors', '0 roofs', 1 shell in 'Single outline corkscrew (vase mode)' in Simpliy3D. Took a little under 4 hours.

For filament, I printed this with MakerGeeks 'Ah Natural (clear)' PLA: 235 deg, at 180mm/sec. I noticed that if I printed slower than 100mm/sec, it would start to get more opaque, and the faster I print, the more clear it gets. My theory is that printing slower allows air bubbles in the filament, and this adds to the opaqueness, while printing fast puts more tension on the filament during extrusion and forces the air out. Just a theory though ;)
Designed in Autodesk Maya, using custom scripts to convert quads to hexagons.

J'ai remarqué que si j'imprimais plus lentement que 100mm / sec, il commencerait à devenir plus opaque, et plus j'imprime vite, plus il devient clair. Ma théorie est que l'impression plus lente permet aux bulles d'air dans le filament, et cela ajoute à l'opacité, tandis que l'impression rapide met plus de tension sur le filament pendant l'extrusion et expulse l'air. Juste une théorie si;)

title: br34ker's Anet A8 Titan V6 Mount

description.text:
This is my mount for the E3D Titan extruder combined with an E3D V6 for the Anet A8 Printer. It fits on the original linear guides. It's cooled by the original 40mm fan and has a 5015 fan for the parts.
I also created a tool mount to interchange with the parts-fan (e.g. for bed leveling with a dial indicator).

It's also updated for mounting a BLTouch-sensor - Beware that it only fits with the E3D V6 nozzle. For the Volcano you need a distancer.
Use following settings for marlin:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -31 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]

define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

I will provide a step-model to the tool mount, so you can easily design your own modules.

Printer:

Creality3D CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

Only the main mount need supports. The rest can be printed without.

This and the other manhole release are the final ones in the basic set of OpenForge Streets.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

For each gutter tile, print yourself one of .gutter. and a base of the same size (2x2, 2x4 or 4x4). The streets are in 25mm square basis (which matches Dwarven Forge). If you want that size, print without changes, and print one of the 25mm bases. If you instead want inch squares, scale the street tile on X and Y by 101.6% and print one of the inch bases. Finally, if you want wyloch style tiles (1.25" per square) scale the X and Y by 127%.

Other Street Tiles

You can find the rest of this set as it gets released, along with some other city street tiles that people from around thingiverse have been creating in the OpenForge 2 Streets Collection

Tronxy X5s

As most of you know, Gearbest provided me with their Tronxy X5s printer. This full set was printed on the printer, and I'm very happy with how they came out. Overall, the Tronxy X5s is now printing better then my Prusa i3 in pretty much every way. I still use both, but I'm doing prints on this printer first in almost every case because they come out with less need for cleanup then the ones on my prusa.

title: OpenForge Cobblestone Streets: Manholes Against Curb

description.text:
This and the other manhole release are the final ones in the basic set of OpenForge Streets. Because the manhole is on the edge of the tile, this set has special bases to handle having to cut out the side.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

For each gutter tile, print yourself one of .gutter. and a base of the same size (2x2, 2x4 or 4x4). The streets are in 25mm square basis (which matches Dwarven Forge). If you want that size, print without changes, and print one of the 25mm bases. If you instead want inch squares, scale the street tile on X and Y by 101.6% and print one of the inch bases. Finally, if you want wyloch style tiles (1.25" per square) scale the X and Y by 127%.

You will also need to print out one of the grates that fits the design of the edge (either rounded or squared).

Other Street Tiles

You can find the rest of this set as it gets released, along with some other city street tiles that people from around thingiverse have been creating in the OpenForge 2 Streets Collection

Tronxy X5s

As most of you know, Gearbest provided me with their Tronxy X5s printer. This full set was printed on the printer, and I'm very happy with how they came out. Overall, the Tronxy X5s is now printing better then my Prusa i3 in pretty much every way. I still use both, but I'm doing prints on this printer first in almost every case because they come out with less need for cleanup then the ones on my prusa.

title: E3D V6 Bowden carriage DL V1.1

description.text:
E3D V6 Bowden carriage.

Designed for maximum accessibility from the front, by placing the fan on the back.

NOW WITH ADJUSTABLE BLTOUCH MOUNT

It should fit just fine on an Anet A8 / AM8 or similar.
Because the fan is mounted on the back, you might need to tap M4 thread in the back of the bearing blocks. (most of the time these are just blank holes)

Currently i've only included a mount for a tronxy (stock anet) sensor and a BLTouch sensor
For BLTouch sensor, mount the BLTouch adapter to the sensor holder and adjust the height to your liking.

Change these settings in marlin’s configuration.h for the tronxy (stock anet) sensor:

  • #define X_MIN_POS -13
  • #define Y_MIN_POS 0
  • #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -30
  • #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
  • #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 30
  • #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190
  • #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 30
  • #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190

Change these settings in marlin’s configuration.h for the BLTOUCH sensor:

  • #define X_MIN_POS -13
  • #define Y_MIN_POS 0
  • #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -34
  • #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -3
  • #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 34
  • #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 186
  • #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 30
  • #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190

Let me know what you think of it!

Change log

V1.1 (12/31/2017)

  • Updated part cooling fan nozzle to much more efficient design
  • Added BLTouch mount.

V1.0 (12/07/2017)

  • Tested all parts
  • Updated description with correct Marlin settings
  • No longer work in progress :)

V0.3 (11/28/2017)

  • Recessed the M4 nut holes on the back of the base plate to allow the M4 screws to be shorter
  • Moved the mounting holes in the build plate for the belt holder more inward to allow for a bit more material around the hole on the outside.
  • Added preliminary Bill of Materials

V0.2 (11/26/2017)

  • Fixed blocked fan duct
  • Moved entire fan down to make sure it is not hitting the upper cross member of the frame
  • Redesigned Fan mount & Fan duct

V0.1 (11/25/2017)

  • Updated Fan duct for better printability

V0.0 (11/25/2017)

  • Initial Version

Printer:

Anet AM8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

No supports should be needed.
Print base + clamp in PETG or ABS
The other parts can be printed in PLA if desired.

Bill of materials

Hot end clamp

  • 2x M4x30 screws
  • 2x M4 nuts

Base plate

  • 12x M4x8 screws

Sensor holder

  • 2x M3x8 screws (longer ones can be used)
  • 2x M3 nuts

BLTouch adapter

  • 2x M3x10 screws
  • 2x M3 nuts

Part cooling fan duct

  • 2x M4x10 screws

Part cooling fan mount

  • 2x M4x8 screws

Fan

  • 1x M4x35 screw (minimum length, longer one can be used)
  • 1x M4 nut

Belt holder

  • 2x M3x18 screws
  • 2x M3 nuts

It was the first Category 5 hurricane to strike the Leeward Islands on record, followed by Hurricane Maria two weeks later, and is unofficially the second-costliest Caribbean hurricane on record, which was also surpassed by Hurricane Maria in the same year.

Hurricane Maria is regarded as the worst natural disaster on record in Dominica and caused catastrophic damage and a major humanitarian crisis in Puerto Rico. The tenth-most intense Atlantic hurricane on record, Maria was the thirteenth named storm, seventh consecutive hurricane, fourth major hurricane, and the second Category 5 hurricane of the hyperactive 2017 Atlantic hurricane season. At its peak, the hurricane caused catastrophic damage and numerous fatalities across the northeastern Caribbean, compounding recovery efforts in the areas of the Leeward Islands already struck by Hurricane Irma just two weeks prior. Maria was the third consecutive major hurricane to threaten the Leeward Islands in two weeks, after Irma made landfall in several of the islands two weeks prior and Hurricane Jose passed dangerously close, bringing tropical storm force winds to Barbuda.

title: AstroLux Led  Bike Light holder Nite Rider clamp

description.text:
The astro lux Led light is the best Led light bargain around. It can also be found on chinese sites like bankgood for $20.

Very strong light with 7 strengths and multiple other modes.

Uses 18645 li ion batteries which charge awesome in a nitecore charger

I made this holder so i could mount my astrolux light on my bike using a great bike clamp from nite rider.

This clamp is inexpensive and allows to point the light up and down and left or right very easily

I could have designed a light holder that could attach to the bike but it wouldnt be as versatile or a strong as this clamp

The 24mm diameter light fits snugly into the holder then clicks into place on the nite rider lumina bike clamp

Nite rider also makes a helmet clamp for this same connector.

author: Leapnlarry

description.text: Hurricane Mitch was the second deadliest Atlantic hurricane on record and the deadliest hurricane observed in the satellite era. The storm was the thirteenth named storm, ninth hurricane, and third major hurricane of the 1998 hurricane season. Along with Hurricane Georges, Mitch was the most notable hurricane in the season for its deaths and destruction. At the time, Hurricane Mitch was the strongest Atlantic hurricane observed in the month of October, though it has since been surpassed by Hurricane Wilma of the 2005 season. In addition, the hurricane is the seventh most intense Atlantic hurricane on record.
Easy level test with less filament needed.

Was planning to experiment with this design on a valveless pulse jet design, the part has been sized to give similar inlet area to that of typical valveless pulsejet.

Diameter 55.43mm
531.86mm2 inlet area

protolabs priced it ~£1300 so have changed design to something that can be CNC made
